title: The rise of the Ottoman Empire - Mostafa Minawi

options.text: B.F. Skinner and Lev Vygotsky

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the major design flaws of personality tests like the MBTI?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too easy to take

options.label: B
options.text: They are too difficult to understand

options.label: C
options.text: They rely on forced-choice questions

options.label: D

options.text: It only measures personality traits, not skills or abilities

options.text: It only applies to certain age groups

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It only measures introversion and extroversion

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one of the ways in which personality is not stable?

options.label: A
options.text: It changes depending on the situation

options.label: B
options.text: It changes during key periods, such as school years or when starting work

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same throughout life

options.label: D
options.text: It is not influenced by upbringing or life experiences

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential negative consequences of using personality tests in institutions?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Climate change will displace millions. Here's how we prepare - Colette Pichon Battle

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's reaction when they first saw the Louisiana flood maps?

options.label: A
options.text: They were surprised and concerned about the land loss in south Louisiana.

options.label: B
options.text: They were angry and frustrated with the government's response to Hurricane Katrina.

options.label: C
options.text: They were relieved that their community was not as affected as others.

options.label: D
options.text: They were indifferent to the maps and did not think they applied to them.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the predicted number of people who will be displaced due to climate change by the end of the next century?

options.label: A
options.text: 100 million

options.label: B
options.text: 180 million

options.label: C
options.text: 300 million

options.label: D
options.text: 500 million

multiple-choice.question: What is climate gentrification, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: A: The process of rebuilding damaged homes with a higher value, but out of reach for low-income communities.

options.label: B
options.text: The displacement of people from coastal areas due to climate change.

options.label: C
options.text: The influx of people moving to coastal areas due to climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: The process of restoring natural habitats and ecosystems affected by climate change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument against the current economic system?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is too focused on profit and not enough on social welfare.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is causing climate change and displacement of people.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is based on an unjust and extractive approach to living on the planet.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is not providing enough resources for disaster recovery.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's call to action for addressing climate change and migration?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on reducing CO2 emissions and investing in technology.

options.label: B
options.text: To restructure our social and economic systems to prioritize justice and fairness.

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a new social attitude that sees migration as a threat to individual privilege.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop cities that can receive people and provide housing, food, water, health care, and freedom from overpolicing.

options.text: "The Ride to Eternity"

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: 10 ways to have a better conversation - Celeste Headlee

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the most overlooked skill that we fail to teach?

options.label: A
options.text: Problem-solving

options.label: B
options.text: Critical thinking

options.label: C
options.text: Conversational competence

options.label: D
options.text: Time management

multiple-choice.question: The speaker advises against pontificating, which means:

options.label: A
options.text: Stating your opinion without giving others a chance to respond

options.label: B
options.text: Sharing your personal experiences to relate to others

options.label: C
options.text: Asking open-ended questions to encourage discussion

options.label: D
options.text: Listening actively to others

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on how to ask questions?

options.label: A
options.text: Start with complicated questions to get a simple answer

options.label: B
options.text: Use open-ended questions that begin with who, what, when, where, why, or how

options.label: C
options.text: Repeat back what the other person has said to show you're listening

options.label: D
options.text: Equate your experience with theirs to relate to the conversation

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do we often fail to listen to each other?

options.label: A
options.text: We're too busy thinking about our own experiences

options.label: B
options.text: We get distracted by our own thoughts

options.label: C
options.text: We're too focused on getting our point across

options.label: D
options.text: We're not interested in what the other person has to say

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final advice on how to have a good conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: Be brief and try to impress others with your knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: Be interested in other people and be prepared to be amazed

options.label: C
options.text: Equate your experience with theirs to relate to the conversation

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat back what the other person has said to show you're listening

title: Why is pneumonia so dangerous? - Eve Gaus and Vanessa Ruiz

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the alveoli in the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: To facilitate gas exchange between the bloodstream and the outside air

options.label: B
options.text: To filter out pathogens from the air we breathe

options.label: C
options.text: To produce mucus to trap invaders

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate body temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is the mucociliary escalator, and what is its role in the respiratory tract?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of white blood cell that defends against foreign organisms

options.label: B
options.text: A mechanism that helps to clear out pathogens from the lungs

options.label: C
options.text: A process that involves the breakdown of mucus to trap invaders

options.label: D
options.text: A type of fluid that builds up in the alveoli due to inflammation

multiple-choice.question: What are some common symptoms of pneumonia, and what is the body's response to the infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid breathing, coughing, and increased mucus production

options.label: B
options.text: Fever, chills, and loss of appetite

options.label: C
options.text: Headache, fatigue, and muscle aches

options.label: D
options.text: Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea

multiple-choice.question: What are some factors that can increase the risk of developing pneumonia, and how can we prevent it?

options.label: A
options.text: Smoking, genetic disorders, and lack of access to healthcare

options.label: B
options.text: Poor diet, lack of exercise, and exposure to pathogens

options.label: C
options.text: Allergies, asthma, and environmental toxins

options.label: D
options.text: Stress, anxiety, and sleep deprivation

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of antibiotics in treating pneumonia, and how can we manage the infection at home?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibiotics help to clear out the infection and reduce inflammation

options.label: B
options.text: Antibiotics only help to alleviate symptoms, not treat the underlying infection

options.label: C
options.text: Antibiotics are not effective in treating pneumonia and should only be used as a last resort

options.label: D
options.text: Antibiotics are not necessary for treating pneumonia and can be managed with rest and hydration

title: Can you solve the Alice in Wonderland riddle? - Alex Gendler

options.text: The Queen claims that 64 is the same as 65, and Alice argues that 64 is actually 65.

options.text: The Queen claims that 64 is the same as 65, and Alice argues that 64 is not the same as 65.

options.text: The Queen claims that 64 is not the same as 65, and Alice argues that 64 is actually the same as 65.

options.label: B
options.text: 40 billion

options.label: C
options.text: 86 billion

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: D
options.text: 300 kilometers per hour

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It wears down and degrades

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The claim is true until proven false

options.label: D
options.text: The claim is false until proven true

title: The hidden treasures of Timbuktu - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: What was the unique location of the city of Timbuktu that made it rich?

options.label: A
options.text: It was located on the edge of the Sahara desert.

options.label: B
options.text: It marked the intersection of two essential trade routes.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a major port city on the Atlantic Ocean.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the capital of the Mali Empire.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the reign of Askia Mohammed Toure on Timbuktu?

options.label: A
options.text: He reversed his predecessor’s regressive policies and encouraged learning.

options.label: B
options.text: He imposed strict rules on the city's population.

options.label: C
options.text: He destroyed many of the city's buildings and manuscripts.

options.label: D
options.text: He made Timbuktu a major military base.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the books produced in Timbuktu?

options.label: A
options.text: They were only used for Islamic studies.

options.label: B
options.text: They were written in a single language.

options.label: C
options.text: They were in high demand among the wealthiest members of society.

options.label: D
options.text: They were only used for practical purposes.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Moroccan king's capture of Timbuktu in 1591?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the beginning of a golden age in Timbuktu.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the imprisonment of Ahmed Baba and other prominent scholars.

options.label: C
options.text: It made Timbuktu a major center of learning.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the destruction of many of the city's buildings.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of the manuscripts of Timbuktu?

options.label: A
options.text: They are all safely stored in a single library.

options.label: B
options.text: They are all available for modern scholars to read.

options.label: C
options.text: Many of them remain lost or hidden in the desert.

options.label: D
options.text: They are all in the process of being translated into modern languages.

title: Which type of milk is best for you? - Jonathan J. O’Sullivan & Grace E. Cunningham

multiple-choice.question: What is the process of turning a plant into a milk-like product?

options.text: Soaking, draining, rinsing, and milling into a thick paste.

options.label: B
options.text: Drying, and milling into flour.

options.label: C

options.label: C

title: The myth of the stolen eyeballs - Nathan D. Horowitz

title: Are all of your memories real? - Daniel L. Schacter

multiple-choice.question: What is one common experience that highlights the unreliability of human memories?

options.label: A
options.text: Forgetting important events

options.label: B
options.text: Incorporating information from outside sources into personal recollections

options.label: C
options.text: Having vivid dreams that feel real

options.label: D
options.text: Being able to recall every detail of a past event

multiple-choice.question: In a study where researchers showed participants a random collection of photographs, including images of a university campus they had never visited, what did a majority of participants say when shown the images three weeks later?

options.label: A
options.text: That they had probably or definitely visited the campus in the past

options.label: B
options.text: That they had never seen the campus before

options.label: C
options.text: That they didn't remember seeing the campus

options.label: D
options.text: That the campus looked familiar but they couldn't recall visiting it

multiple-choice.question: What can happen when our current opinions, feelings, and experiences bias our memories of how we felt in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: We may forget important events

options.label: B
options.text: We may recall events more accurately

options.label: C
options.text: We may recall events in a way that aligns with our current views

options.label: D
options.text: We may not experience any changes in our memories

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The same likelihood of winning as the group who did not know the outcome

options.label: D
options.text: They were not able to rate the likelihood

options.text: They may have no impact on the outcome of the investigation

title: Why people fall for misinformation - Joseph Isaac

multiple-choice.question: What was the main contribution of David Hänig's research to our understanding of taste?

options.label: A
options.text: He discovered that the tongue has a unique shape that affects taste.

options.label: B
options.text: He published the first accurate illustration of the tongue map.

options.label: C
options.text: He analyzed taste sensitivities across the tongue for the four basic flavors.

options.label: D
options.text: He found that the tongue has a fixed number of taste receptors.

multiple-choice.question: What type of misconception is the tongue map, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A misconception comprised of disinformation.

options.label: B
options.text: A misconception comprised of misinformation.

options.label: C
options.text: A misconception that is a mix of both disinformation and misinformation.

options.label: D
options.text: A misconception that is not based on any data.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Hänig's data on the distribution of taste sensitivities across the tongue?

options.label: A
options.text: He found that each taste was detected at a specific location on the tongue.

options.label: B
options.text: He found that the maximum sensation for each taste varied across the tongue.

options.label: C
options.text: He found that the areas he identified offered very small variations in intensity.

options.label: D
options.text: He found that the tongue had no sensitivity to any of the four basic flavors.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the tongue map spread so easily, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was a complex and nuanced concept that required a deep understanding of science.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was a simple and easy-to-understand concept that appealed to people's desire for clear stories.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was a well-funded research project that received widespread media attention.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was a widely accepted concept that was already well-established in the scientific community.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a misconception that challenges the idea of the tongue map, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The existence of umami as a basic taste.

options.label: B
options.text: The existence of tastes like fatty, alkaline, metallic, and water-like.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that the tongue has a fixed number of taste receptors.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that the tongue map is a widely accepted concept in the scientific community.

title: The rise of modern populism - Takis S. Pappas

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the charismatic leader who came to power in Greece in 1981 and promised to govern for the betterment of the "common people"?

options.label: A
options.text: Andreas Papandreou

options.label: B
options.text: Nikos Samaras

options.label: C
options.text: Konstantinos Karamanlis

options.label: D
options.text: Georgios Papadopoulos

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the type of democracy that has three essential components: accepting society's divisions, requiring common ground, and relying on the rule of law and minority rights?

options.label: A
options.text: Populism

options.label: B
options.text: Liberal Democracy

options.label: C
options.text: Authoritarianism

options.label: D
options.text: Fascism

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument made by modern populist candidates, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: That institutions like courtrooms and free press are essential for protecting individual and social rights.

options.label: B
options.text: That institutions like courtrooms and free press are run by a self-serving ruling minority.

options.label: C
options.text: That the majority of a population feels their interests are underrepresented and needs a new kind of leader.

options.label: D
options.text: That the will of the people should be above the institutions that protect individual and social rights.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon of a charismatic leader identifying themselves as embodying the "will of the people" and placing the interests of the people above institutions?

options.label: A
options.text: Populism

options.label: B
options.text: Authoritarianism

options.label: C
options.text: Fascism

options.label: D
options.text: Nationalism

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of modern populist leaders on political discourse, the rule of law, and public trust, even when they don't follow through with their most extreme promises?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a long-lasting positive impact on all three areas.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a short-term positive impact on two areas and a long-term negative impact on the third.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a profoundly destabilizing impact on liberal democracy.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no impact on any of the three areas.
